aws::graph::propositions: # McDonnell Douglas Helicopter 500N Landing Gear Collapse Incident
A McDonnell Douglas Helicopter (MDHI) 500N with registration N522GS experienced a landing gear collapse on April 18, 2014.
The incident occurred at approximately 1340 Pacific daylight time (PDT).
The incident took place at Santa Monica Airport (SMO) in Santa Monica, California.
The right rear landing gear strut failed during landing.
The front strut collapsed while attempting to set the helicopter on the ground.
The helicopter was operated under the provisions of 14 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 91.
The owner of the helicopter was also the pilot of the flight.
The private pilot was not injured in the incident.
Three passengers were on board the helicopter.
None of the three passengers were injured in the incident.
The helicopter sustained substantial damage to the front landing gear structure.
The flight was a local personal flight.
The flight departed from Camarillo, California.
The flight departed at approximately 1315 PDT.
The planned destination of the flight was Santa Monica.
Visual meteorological conditions prevailed during the flight.
No flight plan had been filed for the flight.
The pilot reported slowly setting the helicopter down on a landing pad.
The pilot felt the helicopter "drastically" slip to the right during landing.
The pilot lifted the helicopter off the pad after feeling it slip.
A passenger on board verified the right strut was broken.
A passenger reported hearing a "loud pop" on touchdown.
The helicopter was a 1993 McDonnell Douglas 500N model.
The helicopter was subject to Airworthiness Directive (AD) 2007-12-23.
AD 2007-12-23 required modifications to the strut and fairings.
AD 2007-12-23 required continuing inspections of the landing gear.
The AD referenced MD Helicopter Service Bulletin SB500N-022.
MD Helicopter Service Bulletin SB500N-022 described the required modifications.
The increased size of the rivet hole suggested that the modifications had been performed.
The polished surface around the hole suggested that the modifications had been performed.
The AD required an initial dye penetrant inspection.
The AD required continuing 10x magnified visual inspections.
The inspections were required at intervals not exceeding every 100 hours time in service.
The inspections were also required during each annual inspection.
According to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), AD 2007-12-23 was complied with at an airframe total time of 2,248.3 hours.
At the time of the accident, the total airframe time was reported as 2,274 hours.

text:
# Factual Information

## History of Flight

| Landing | Landing gear collapse (Defining event) |
| --- | --- |

### HISTORY OF FLIGHT

On April 18, 2014, about 1340 Pacific daylight time (PDT), a McDonnell Douglas Helicopter (MDHI) 500N, N522GS, right rear landing gear strut failed during landing, and while attempting to set the helicopter on the ground, the front strut also collapsed at Santa Monica Airport (SMO), Santa Monica, California. The owner/pilot was operating the helicopter under the provisions of 14 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 91. The private pilot and three passengers were not injured; the helicopter sustained substantial damage to the front landing gear structure. The local personal flight departed Camarillo, California, about 1315, with a planned destination of Santa Monica. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed, and no flight plan had been filed.

The pilot reported that on landing he slowly sat the helicopter down on a landing pad and felt the helicopter "drastically" slip to the right. He then lifted the helicopter off the pad at which time a passenger on board verified the right strut was broken. A passenger reported that on touchdown he heard a "loud pop."

### AIRCRAFT AND AIRWORTHINESS DIRECTIVE

The 1993 McDonnell Douglas 500N helicopter was subject to Airworthiness Directive (AD) 2007-12-23, requiring modifications to the strut and fairings and continuing inspections. The AD references MD Helicopter Service Bulletin SB500N-022 that describes the modifications. The increased size of the rivet hole and the polished surface around the hole suggest that the modifications had been performed. The AD required an initial dye penetrant inspection followed by continuing 10x magnified visual inspections at intervals not to exceed every 100 hours time in service or during each annual inspection. According to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), AD 2007-12-23 was complied with at a airframe total time of 2,248.3; at the time of the accident the a total airframe time of 2,274 was reported.
